content.description: Crux tends to be the head game. Dig deep and just get yourself some more of that white courage from your chalk bag.
content.protection: Sport with fixed rap anchors.
content.location: Route is 50 feet to the left of Gold Nugget. See photo for more details.

content.description: Crux is moving up onto the upper ledge.
content.protection: Mixed (if needed), few bolts then fixed rap anchors above the upper mantle ledge.
content.location: Same general start as What's Left, then continue straight up.

content.description: Crux is on the middle steep slab face. Note that this area is new and will have a greater chance of potential loose rock.
content.protection: Mixed, several draws then a few cam or nut placements before reaching the fixed rap anchors.
content.location: Left side trad slab area.

content.description: Great beginner traditional lead!
content.protection: Standard Rack recommended with fixed rap anchors.
content.location: Far left (north) side of Providence Main Bluff.

content.description: Crux is around the first bolt but is designed for beginners learning to lead and set up rap station.
content.protection: Draws and rap gear for anchors
content.location: Climb the lower slab, just right of Ancient Sea Friends, to the two rap anchors. repeat as needed.

content.description: This is the first bolted line to the right of ProvidenceCrack. Sustained climbing with the crux coming at the end. If you are at this cliff and think you might be able to get up a 5.12, you should get on this climb. Might be the best climb at the cliff.
content.protection: bolts to anchors
content.location: first bolted line right of providence crack

content.description: Three different route sections divide this route visualy into what can be descriped as bottom, middle and top crux transitions. The bottom crux is a balancy moderate layback, while the steep, middle buldge crux requires the use of an assortment of pockets, pinches, crimpers and slopers to gain the next secure jug. This middle crux can be bypassed by moving right a couple steps and climbing around using bigger holds. The top crux section forces fancy foot work and attetion to the little details while managing the left-facing edge.
content.protection: Seven or eight quickdraws, then a couple runnrs for the use fo shared rap anchors with the route "Next Time Send A Card." The last two bolts have perma-draws to lower off of, in case someone is currently climbing the other route.
content.location: Just right of "Slimestone Cowboy" and left of "Next Time Send A Card," RETURN TO SENDER follows a relatively straight line of bolts up to the middle roof buldge then flows back right towards Next Time Send A Card rap anchors.

content.description: A thin sequence down low leads to long powerful moves up high. Harder for shorter people. Three star movement and one star rock quality. Be careful in the spring.
content.protection: Five bolts to a two bolt anchor. One bolt is a fixed chain.
content.location: On the far right hand side of the buttress; last route on the right.

content.description: This climb follows the obvious crack up the middle of the face, and is one of the classics in the Columbia area. Start with a wide chimney, then grovel into an offwidth section. Bring large cams to protect this part. After the offwidth, continue climbing up a good and easy-to-protect hand crack until you get to a small roof, and the crack becomes more of a water groove. Place all the tricams you own on a shelf under the roof, then gun for the top. The crux occurs right when your feet get to the last piece of gear, but the runout after the crux is easy. This is a well-protected climb, but if you are not comfortable at 5.10, then there may be some major air time at the crux.
content.protection: tricams, large cams (black diamond 2 and up)
content.location: large crack in middle of bluff

content.description: Prospector Traverse starts on My First Rodeo then heads right, following a crack traverse under the upper mantle ledge. Continue right to the rap anchors on White Courage.
content.protection: Standard rack with cams to fixed rap anchors.
content.location: Left side trad slab area.

content.description: Start up slab with loose rock to solid vertical face. High Banker heads straight up so continue moving up right to climb the right side of the upper ledge then continue up to the rap anchors.
content.protection: Sport to fixed rap anchors.
content.location: Left side trad slab area. See pic for route line.

content.description: This climb is the bolted climb left of ProvidenceCrack,? and was put up by the route artist, Jim Karpowicz. Climb up past two bolts to a crack in a right-facing dihedral. Protect the crack, then go right back onto the face to an undercling and a hard clip from the undercling. After getting the clip, pull a well-protected crux, then run it out to the top. The bottom offers some attention-getting moves, and the protection in the dihedral is probably good, but there is a good chance it would get tested if the leader is not comfortable at 5.10.
content.protection: Gear: despite 3 bolts, this route can take a variety of gear. i (btw) advise that you take mid-large wires for the dihedral, and a couple of cams in the thin-hands to wide-hands range for the shelf.
content.location: first bolted route left of providence crack

content.description: The hardest climbing is at the roof, but the upper corner contains some non-obvious and very interesting climbing.
content.protection: This route starts thirty feet right of providence crack, pulling a small roof on its way towards a right facing corner. It follows seven bolts to a two-bolt anchor. This well-protected line is a perfect beginners route with lots of easy climbing and prono
content.location: 2 routes to the right of providence crack

content.description: Part of the left side trad ramp area. Great for a beginner traditional lead.
content.protection: Standard rack recommended, fixed rap anchors
content.location: Left side of Providence main bluff

content.description: The crux is obvious and requires some power, a Few good smears and a lay back on a sloper. Looking forward to your comments. Three routes utilize the same start on BOTH GET HARD ON TOP: Gold Nugget (left), Fist of Gold (center), and Moon Shine (right)
content.protection: Sport climb with Rap anchors
content.location: First line of bolts just 10 feet right of Gold Nugget, utilizing the same start as Both Get Hard On Top, then following bolts right and up a short, rounded, roof arete.

content.protection: 8 bolts + Rap Anchors
content.location: These routes are 15 meters left of the obvious, classic Providence Crack. Just left, at the top of root ladder approach trail, a ripple slab bulge fades to a vertical face just pasted a softball sized pocket. Look for steep, "holy****" provoking double overhang!

content.description: Crux is upper mantle.
content.protection: Sport to fixed anchors above upper mantle ledge.   Shares anchors with Prospector.
content.location: Head up the same lower start then move right and up to a couple bolts on face. Continue straight up over small roof on to mantle ledge. Fixed anchors are up and right.

content.description: Several different crux sections provide different challenges, from a solid dead-point move,on the vertical face, to the use of slopers, while managing the small roofs, this route provides a bit of fun variety.
content.protection: Seven or eight quickdraws plus a couple long runners to secure yourself at the two bolt chain rap anchor. 50M rope works just fine.
content.location: FRIGHT FLIGHT follows a straight line of bolts just right of "Next Time Send A Card" and just left of "Edge of Darkness." Feel free to use the first bolt on either of the two routes to begin your ascent.

content.protection: 6 bolts + Rap Anchors
content.location: 45' (15M) left of Providence Crack, climb GOLD NUGGET though the crux and clip bolt on the right, just below the upper flake. Continue out right and up balance moves to the rap anchors.

content.description: Several crux point fall along this line. The first is a couple moves after pulling onto the steep middle section. The next crux is at the second small upper roof. The route follows a line dividing the light and dark rock.
content.protection: Sport then fixed rap anchors.
content.location: Just left of Ancient Sea Friends.

content.description: This line follows pockets up a steep face to an upper right arete, then finishes with a slab traverse left to a flake and rap anchors.
content.protection: Sport to fixed rap anchors.
content.location: First route left of Prohibition and shares the same start and bolt. Immediately head up and left to follow Distillery bolt line.

content.description: Great for top roping. Route better left to experienced leaders if you are considering the trad option.
content.protection: Standard rack, fixed rap anchors.
content.location: Just right of My First Rodeo, left side of main bluff.

content.description: Both Get Hard On Top (11a) is the first 45 feet (15M) of Gold Nugget. Climb the slab up to the vertical face where a pocket allows for the second clip before engaging the balancy transitions before and after the third bolt. Once you gain the "self of gold", move left and hug the "Gold Nugget"! Great holds provide an easy reach up to a large pocket from which the last bolt can be clipped to complete and lower from "Both Get Hard On Top", avoiding the hard crux sequence of Gold Nugget 12+.
content.protection: 5 QD (please leave permanent chain draw)
content.location: 45ft (15M) left of Providence Crack

content.description: Bootlegger is a great combination of slab, layback crack, face, and roof moves. The crux is in the roof section after the face traverse.
content.protection: Quick draws, feel free to take a cam for the flake, end at rap anchors
content.location: Start this line following a thin slab seem to the upper face. Line starts 20 feet right of Step by Step.

climbs.name: Ancient Sea Friends
climbs.fa: Lead on gear by Ben Williams, Equipped by Kevin Capps

content.description: Climb the easy warm up slab, do some stretches on the ledge, and then wedge yourself in the dihedrel and get ready to hang on for the next 20 feet.  The crux is very balancy and you will know it when you come to it!
content.protection: 6 bolts and 2 bolt anchor
content.location: look for the giant dihedrel. just right of next time, send a card

content.description: The Main Wall at Providence truly offers one of the state's better options for 5.12 sport climbing. Newer lines such as Gold Nugget and Return to Sender offer excellent support to classic trad and sport lines such as the super-classic layback Prohibition, Providence Crack, and Slimestone Cowboy. There is likely more potential for hard routes and linkups in this area. Take the grades with a grain of salt as many routes have seen very few ascents; things are still cleaning up, breaking off, and developing consensus.
